hints.content: On a parabola, the **vertex** is the point where the graph changes from increasing to decreasing or vice versa.

The graph changes from increasing to decreasing at the point $(-3, 4)$; the graph has a positive slope to the left of $(-3, 4)$ and a negative slope to its right.

[[☃ image 1]]
**$(-3, 4)$ are the coordinates of the vertex of the parabola.**

question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

The graph of $y=-(x+3)^2+4$ is shown in the $xy$-plane. What are the coordinates of the vertex of the parabola?

[[☃ radio 1]]

---

[Show calculator](/r/dsat_desmos_calculator)

options.alt: The equation y=-(x+3)^2+4 is graphed in the xy-plane. The graph is a parabola that opens downward. The graph crosses the x-axis at -5 and -1. The graph crosses the y-axis at -5. The graph changes from increasing to decreasing at the point (-3, 4).

choices.clue: This point is a zero ($x$-intercept) of the graph.

The vertex is the point on the parabola where the graph changes from increasing to decreasing or vice versa.

The graph changes from increasing to decreasing at the point $(-3, 4)$.
This point is a zero ($x$-intercept) of the graph.
This point is the $y$-intercept of the graph.
